quiz_metadata.title: Java Collections: Sets and Maps
quiz_metadata.description: This quiz covers the main concepts of sets and maps in Java, including HashSet, TreeSet, HashMap, and TreeMap.

questions.question_text: Why do Java collections require wrapper classes for primitive types?

options.text: Because primitive types are not objects
Because wrapper classes are faster
Because wrapper classes are more secure
Because wrapper classes are more efficient

questions.explanation: Java collections can only store objects, and primitive types need to be wrapped in objects to be stored in collections (00:38-00:45).

questions.question_text: What is the main difference between HashSet and TreeSet?

options.text: HashSet is faster, but TreeSet is slower
TreeSet is faster, but HashSet is slower
HashSet stores elements in a specific order, but TreeSet does not
HashSet does not store elements in a specific order, but TreeSet does

questions.explanation: HashSet is faster, but it does not store elements in a specific order. TreeSet is slower, but it stores elements in a specific order (04:42-04:54).

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'contains' method in a Set?

options.text: To add an element to the set
To remove an element from the set
To check if an element is in the set
To clear the set

questions.explanation: The 'contains' method is used to check if an element is in the set (02:43-02:49).

questions.question_text: What is the difference between a Map's key and value?

options.text: A key is unique, but a value can be duplicated
A value is unique, but a key can be duplicated
A key and value are both unique
A key and value are both duplicated

questions.explanation: In a Map, a key is unique, but a value can be duplicated (05:38-05:45).

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'put' method in a Map?

options.text: To add a new key-value pair to the map
To remove a key-value pair from the map
To update a key-value pair in the map
To clear the map

questions.explanation: The 'put' method is used to add a new key-value pair to the map or update an existing one (06:50-06:57).

questions.question_text: What is the main difference between HashMap and TreeMap?

options.text: HashMap is faster, but TreeMap is slower
TreeMap is faster, but HashMap is slower
HashMap stores keys in a specific order, but TreeMap does not
HashMap does not store keys in a specific order, but TreeMap does

questions.explanation: HashMap is faster, but it does not store keys in a specific order. TreeMap is slower, but it stores keys in a specific order (09:58-10:07).

questions.question_text: What happens when you try to add a duplicate key to a Map?

options.text: It throws an exception
It adds a new key-value pair
It updates the existing key-value pair
It ignores the duplicate key

questions.explanation: When you try to add a duplicate key to a Map, it updates the existing key-value pair (07:27-07:35).

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the 'get' method in a Map?

options.text: To add a new key-value pair to the map
To remove a key-value pair from the map
To retrieve the value associated with a key
To clear the map

questions.explanation: The 'get' method is used to retrieve the value associated with a key (07:04-07:11).

questions.question_text: What happens when you try to retrieve a value from a Map using a key that does not exist?

options.text: It throws an exception
It returns null
It returns a default value
It creates a new key-value pair

questions.explanation: When you try to retrieve a value from a Map using a key that does not exist, it returns null.

questions.question_text: What is the main advantage of using a TreeMap over a HashMap?

options.text: TreeMap is faster
TreeMap stores keys in a specific order
TreeMap uses less memory
TreeMap is more secure

questions.explanation: The main advantage of using a TreeMap over a HashMap is that TreeMap stores keys in a specific order (09:58-10:07).
